data.name: Eastern Tiger Swallowtail
data.hostplant: Many including poplar, willow, maple, elm, sassafras
data.habitat: Prefers open areas near water, fields, roadsides, backyards
funfacts: North Carolina’s state butterfly; our most common swallowtail
Like other swallowtails, females have more blue on hindwing
Females can have either a light or a dark form
In photo from left to right: female dark form, male, female light (yellow) form

data.name: Black Swallowtail
data.hostplant: Members of the parsley family such as Queen Anne’s lace, carrot, celery, dill, fennel
data.habitat: Open sunny areas, marshes, roadsides, backyards; Avoids woods and shaded areas
funfacts: Will readily lay eggs on parsley planted in your garden
Like all swallowtails, the caterpillar has a hidden organ that looks like a snake’s tongue. It comes out when the caterpillar is disturbed and emits a foul odor to deter predators
Mimics toxic Pipevine Swallowtail to avoid predators

data.name: Spicebush Swallowtail
data.hostplant: Spicebush, sassafras
data.habitat: Open sunny areas, marshes, roadsides, backyards, open woodlands, woodland edges
funfacts: Continuously flutters while feeding
Has a series of pale blue half-moons near edge of hindwings
Mimics toxic Pipevine Swallowtail to avoid predators
During the day, caterpillars live in shelters of folded-over leaves and come out at night to f

data.name: Pipevine Swallowtail
data.hostplant: Virginia snakeroot, pipevines
data.habitat: A variety of open habitats, open woodland, woodland edges
funfacts: Obtains moisture and nutrients at puddles, mud, or animal manure
One of the few butterflies that lays its eggs in clusters
Poisonous to predators because as caterpillars, they eat toxic pipevine
Other non-poisonous butterflies copy (mimic) the Pipeline Swallowtail to deter predators

data.name: Zebra Swallowtail
data.hostplant: Pawpaw
data.habitat: Moist woodlands and surrounding open areas near pawpaw
funfacts: Males often visit puddles to drink
flightis swift
Longest “tails” of our swallowtails
Short proboscis so can’t nectar on long tubular flowers
Named for zebra-like stripes

data.name: Falcate Orangetip
data.hostplant: Plants in the mustard family including toothwort, rock cress
data.habitat: Open moist woodlands and woodland edges, bottomlands
funfacts: One of the earliest fliers - a sign that spring is near
Very short flight period in early spring
Female lacks orange wing tips

data.name: Cabbage White & Sleepy Orange
data.wingspan: Cabbage White: 1.3 - 1.9 inches; Sleepy Orange: 1.4 - 2.3” inches
data.hostplant: Cabbage White: Plants in mustard family, cabbage; Sleepy Orange: Members of the pea family
data.habitat: Sunny open habitats, especially with flowers; roadsides; backyards
funfacts: Cabbage White: One of the earliest butterflies to emerge
Cabbage White: Females can lay 1,000 eggs in a lifetime
Sleepy Orange: Called “sleepy” because it lacks underwing eyespots seen on other similar species
Sleepy Orange: Migrates south in winter

data.name: Orange Sulphur & Cloudless Sulphur
data.wingspan: Orange Sulphur: 1.4 - 2.8 inches; Cloudless Sulphur: 2.3 - 3.2 inches
data.hostplant: Plants in the pea family such as clover, alfalfa, vetch
data.habitat: Open sunny areas, backyards, roadsides
data.flightperiod: March - November, but may be seen any month
funfacts: Orange Sulphur: Orange on upper wings shows in flight
Orange Sulphur: Female can be yellow or nearly white
Cloudless Sulphur: Larger and paler than other sulphurs in our area
Cloudless Sulphur: Caterpillars are camouflaged by what they eat, turning green from green leaves and yellow from yellow blooms

data.name: Gray & Red-banded Hairstreak
data.hostplant: Gray: Many plants, often from pea and mallow families; Red-banded: Fallen leaves of sumacs, oaks, wax myrtle
data.habitat: Gray: Open, dry sunny areas, backyards; Red-banded: Anywhere, but prefers wet wooded areas
funfacts: Hairstreaks have false eye spots and false antennae on hindwings to fool would-be predators
Gray: The most commonly seen hairstreak
Red-banded: Unique in that caterpillar eats dead leaves

data.name: Eastern Tailed-Blue
data.hostplant: Plants in the pea family, such as clover, alfalfa, vetch
data.habitat: Open, dry sunny areas; backyards
funfacts: Commonly seen drinking from puddles or mud
When wings are closed, appears grey with orange false eyespots
When nectaring, tails beneath the false eyespots twitch, making it look more like a head than a tail to distract predators

data.name: American Snout
data.hostplant: Hackberries
data.habitat: In or near hardwood forests with hackberries
funfacts: Named for long labial palps that look like a snout
Has a fast, erratic style of flight
Adults overwinter and may be seen on warm winter days
When at rest, looks like a dead leaf

data.name: Great Spangled Fritillary
data.hostplant: Violets
data.habitat: Sunny open habitats, especially wet areas; pastures
funfacts: Named for silvery white “spangles” on underside of hindwing (seen in photo)
Largest of all North American fritillarie
Females lay eggs on violets and can find them even after they have wilted and blown away

data.name: Variegated Fritillary
data.hostplant: Many - including violets, pansies, passion-flowers, mayapples
data.habitat: Sunny open habitats, roadsides, backyards, pastures
funfacts: Underside lacks the silver “spangles” of Great Spangled Fritillary
Eggs laid singly on stems and leaves; caterpillars eat leaves and flowers
Like all butterflies, it can see ultraviolet light and the colors red, green, and yellow

data.name: Gulf Fritillary
data.hostplant: Passion flowers
data.habitat: Sunny open habitats, roadsides, backyards, pastures
data.flightperiod: August - November; only a migrant in our area
funfacts: Fairly common in late summer and fall as individuals migrate north
Cannot tolerate cold and therefore does not survive the winter here
Females lay as many as 2,000 eggs in a lifetime

data.name: Pearl Crescent
data.hostplant: Asters
data.habitat: Sunny open habitats, roadsides, backyards
funfacts: One of our most common butterflies
Named for silvery crescent on underside of hindwing
Typically lands with wings spread
Despite small size, it defends its territory by attacking intruders
Courtship involves a chase and wing fluttering ritual

data.name: Question Mark & Eastern Comma
data.wingspan: Question Mark: 2.3 - 3 inches; Eastern Comma 1.8 - 2.5” inches
data.hostplant: Question Mark: Elms, hackberries, nettles; Comma: Nettles, elms
data.habitat: Wooded areas with some open space, woodland edges, moist areas
funfacts: Names come from silvery-white “question mark” or “comma” markings on hindwings
Don't visit flowers, but drinks from rotten fruit, tree sap, dung
Mimic dead leaves when wings are folded
Spring forms are reddish; fall forms are brown

data.name: American Lady & Painted Lady
data.wingspan: American Lady: 1.8 - 2.6 inches; Painted Lady: 2.0 - 2.9 inches
data.hostplant: American: Members of the sunflower family; Painted: Many, including thistle, mallow, hollyhock
data.habitat: Sunny open areas often with low vegetation, roadsides, backyards, parks
funfacts: Both feed on flower nectar and rotting fruit
American Lady has two large eyespots on hindwing. Painted Lady has 4-5 smaller eyespots on hindwing
Painted Lady populations don’t last through the winter; must be recolonized each year from individuals migrating from south

data.name: Common Buckeye
data.hostplant: Plantains, snapdragon, gerardia
data.habitat: Sunny open habitats with low vegetation, some bare ground preferred; backyards; roadsides
funfacts: Large false eyespots to scare away predators
Migrates south, often in large flocks, cannot tolerate freezing temperatures
Caterpillars build up toxins from eating their host plants which protects them from predatory ants

data.name: Red-spotted Purple
data.hostplant: Leaves of hardwood trees: cherry, cottonwood, oak, etc.
data.habitat: In or near hardwood forests, woodland edges
funfacts: May visit flowers but prefers sap, rotting fruit, carrion, dung
Often seen on the ground puddling or basking in the sun
Mimics the poisonous Pipevine Swallowtail in color and flight but lacks the tail
The brown and cream caterpillar mimics a bird dropping, protecting it from predators

data.name: Viceroy
data.hostplant: Trees in the willow family: willows, poplars, cottonwoods
data.habitat: Moist open, shrubby areas often near willows
funfacts: Mimics poisonous Monarch butterfly to avoid predation
Curved black line in hindwing distinguishes it from Monarch
Often feeds on dung and decaying matter in addition to flowers
Both the caterpillar and chrysalis mimic bird droppings to protect them from predators

data.name: Hackberry Emperor
data.hostplant: Hackberries, sugarberries
data.habitat: Wooded roadsides, wooded streams, usually near host plant
funfacts: Doesn’t visit flowers, but feeds on sap, rotting fruit, carrion
Likes to land on people to drink perspiration
Often perches on trees trunks, typically head down (see photo)
Males perch for hours on trees in sunny areas looking for females

data.name: Carolina Satyr
data.hostplant: Grasses, including invasive Japanese stilt grass
data.habitat: Hardwood and mixed forests, especially woods with open areas or paths with grasses; also seen at woodland edges
funfacts: Doesn’t visit flowers, but feeds on sap and rotting fruit
Stays low to ground with bouncy flight
Very common butterfly in shaded woods with grassy paths
Adult life expectancy only 6.25 days in mid-summer in the wild

data.name: Monarch
data.hostplant: Exclusively milkweed species
data.habitat: Anywhere during migration; other times usually near milkweed, fields, woodland borders, power strips
funfacts: Migrates south to Mexico in the fall, flying up to 250 miles per day, longest insect migration on Earth
Poisonous to birds and other predators due to milkweed poisons
Orange and black color pattern warns predators, “Don’t eat me, I’m poisonous!”
Males have black scent pouches on hind wings (see photo)

data.name: Juvenal’s & Horace’s Duskywing
data.hostplant: Oaks
data.habitat: Almost anywhere but prefers woodland edges and openings, roadsides
data.flightperiod: Juvenal’s: March - May; Horace’s: June - October
funfacts: Very similar, common, and related species; best told apart by time of year. Flight: Juvenal’s only in spring, Horace’s later
Juvenal’s often land on bare ground
Horace’s more likely to venture into backyards

data.name: Silver-spotted Skipper
data.hostplant: Woody legumes such as locusts, sennas, wisteria
data.habitat: Woodland edges, clearings, fields, roadsides, backyards
funfacts: Named for large silver spot on hindwing (more white than silver)
Largest skipper in our area; has fast, zippy flight
Perches upside down under leaves at night and on hot or cloudy days
Unlike other butterflies, the chrysalis is encased in a loose cocoon among the leaf litter

data.name: Common Checkered-Skipper
data.hostplant: Plants in the mallow family, such as hollyhock, hibiscus
data.habitat: Sunny open places with low vegetation, roadsides, backyards, pastures
data.flightperiod: March - December, more common September - November
funfacts: Stays close to ground, prefers flowers like clover
Typically holds wings open when landed
Hair-like scales cover body, casting a lovely bluish hue in sunlight
Like all skippers, flies so fast it can outpace a horse

data.name: Fiery Skipper
data.hostplant: Grasses
data.habitat: Open sunny areas, roadsides, backyards
funfacts: Often perch with wings partially open
Large eyes, short antennae, stout bodies
Named for fiery pattern on upper hindwing
Males and females similar

data.name: Zabulon Male Skipper
data.hostplant: Grasses
data.habitat: Damp areas near woodlands, streamside paths
funfacts: Often perch with wings partially open
Large eyes, short antennae, stout bodies
Zabulon females are all dark

data.name: Sachem Female Skipper
data.hostplant: Grasses
data.habitat: Open sunny areas, roadsides, backyards
funfacts: Often perch with wings partially open
Large eyes, short antennae, stout bodies
Sachem males are mostly orange

data.name: Clouded Skipper
data.hostplant: Grasses
data.habitat: Open sunny areas, roadsides, backyards
funfacts: Often perch with wings partially open
Large eyes, short antennae, stout bodies
Males and females similar
